prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "Am I the Asshole?" story is in the wrong. So, the situation is that the guy and his girlfriend live together. He wants to play games with his friends, but she's upset because she feels like she has to make plans every time he wants to game, otherwise she's left with nothing to do. The author argues that she doesn't need to go out every time he plays, just relax or use his laptop. She goes to her sister's house for a few hours when he plays.

Hmm, so from the girlfriend's perspective, she might feel neglected when he's gaming and she's left alone. She might want quality time together instead of him just playing games. The author is saying that he's offering her to watch or talk while he plays, but she doesn't want that. So maybe the problem is communication. The author says he told her he's going to play and offered other options, but she still feels like she's being left out. 

But the author also mentions that the girlfriend wants constant attention. So maybe there's a balance issue here. The author wants his gaming time, which is his personal time, but the girlfriend feels like that time is taking away from the time they could spend together. 

In relationships, it's important to find a balance between individual needs and couple time. The author is trying to assert his need for personal time, which is reasonable. But if the girlfriend is feeling lonely or neglected when he's gaming, then maybe the author should have considered that. However, the author isn't forcing her to do anything; he's just playing games and allowing her to do her own thing. 

The girlfriend might be feeling like her needs aren't being met, but the author is also meeting his needs. It's possible that the author isn't in the wrong because he's communicating his intentions and giving his girlfriend options. However, there's a lack of compromise. The author could be more considerate in finding middle ground, like setting specific times for gaming versus couple time. 

But according to the story, the author isn't forcing her to make plans every time. He tells her she can just relax. So maybe the girlfriend is overreacting. The author is standing his ground, which is his right. So maybe the answer is B, the author isn't in the wrong. However, some might argue that he's not being considerate enough. But given the information, the author is trying to communicate and offer alternatives, so he's not entirely at fault. The girlfriend might need to adjust her expectations. So probably B.
